summary: Compare the U.S. and Japanese economies by inflation, interest rate, labor force growth and more.

headline: Treasury to Sell $50 Billion
summary: The offerings comprise $25 billion in four-week bills and $25 billion of 56-day cash-management bills.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Oct. 13, 2010

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Oct. 13, 2010

headline: Dim Sum at Red Egg
summary: Dim sum isn't just for the weekend. At Red Egg, the tiny dishes are available at lunch every day.(See related article.)

headline: Six NATO Personnel Die in Afghanistan
summary: A pair of roadside bombs and a gunbattle with Taliban insurgents left six coalition service members dead Wednesday.

headline: Yashili Looks to Raise $458 Million in IPO
summary: Yashili International Holdings, a Chinese infant-formula maker in which U.S. investment firm Carlyle Group owns a stake, is planning to raise as much as US$458 million in a initial public offering this month on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, according to people familiar with the plans.

headline: J.P. Morgan's Strength Pays Dividends
summary: Dividend days may soon be here again—at least for J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Tribune Suspends Executive
summary: Tribune Co. suspended its chief innovation officer, Lee Abrams, in the wake of a memo he sent to staff Monday that included links to material considered inappropriate.

headline: Citigroup Is Sued for Discrimination
summary: Six current and former female employees sued Citigroup, claiming the company operates at an outdated "boys club" and turns a blind eye to discrimination against women.

headline: PC Sales Rise, but at Slower Pace
summary: Global shipments of personal computers posted a weaker-than-expected rise in the third quarter as softening consumer-PC demand and interest in new tablet devices weighed on unit sales.

headline: Einhorn's New Short: St. Joe
summary: Hedge-Fund honcho David Einhorn says real-estate developer St. Joe Co. is overvalued.

headline: U.S. Porridge Champ Ends Sweet Reign
summary: Defending champ Bob's Red Mill Natural Foods Inc. is returning empty-handed from the Scottish Highlands, where it competed in the 17th annual Golden Spurtle World Porridge Making Championship.

headline: Melding Morgans
summary: Although Morgan Stanley is no longer on the menu, the vision of a grand reunification for the House of Morgan perhaps still lurks in the back of Mr. Dimon's mind. When asked by Morgan Stanley analyst Betsy Graseck on Wednesday's earnings call who he might acquire next, the J.P. Morgan CEO needled her, saying: "I can't tell you that," before adding, "Think about Morgan, the other Morgan."

headline: NFL, Nike Stitch Apparel Deal
summary: The NFL said it will split its apparel licensing rights among seven companies starting in April 2012 as it granted Nike highly-coveted on-field apparel rights.

headline: Russian Consumers Come in From the Cold
summary: Russia may be rich in resources, but increasingly it is the spending power of 140 million Russians as their living standards rise to catch up with the rest of Europe that is exciting the interests of investors.

headline: Options Bears Pounce on St. Joe
summary: Traders made a beeline to the real-estate development company after one hedge-fund manager said the stock was overvalued.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Oct. 14
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Oct. 14

headline: ASML's Net Profit Soars
summary: Dutch semiconductor-equipment maker ASML said its third-quarter net profit soared as customers boosted their investments in chip-making materials.

headline: EU Seeks to Overhaul Audit System
summary: Michel Barnier, the European Union's internal markets chief, launched a consultation over the future of the audit profession Wednesday, saying the sector needs greater competition and questioning its practices.

headline: Broughton No Stranger to Tough Battles
summary: Martin Broughton, the man at the center of the Liverpool Football Club takeover saga, is used to turbulent times.

headline: Broadcom Buys 4G Chip Maker
summary: Broadcom is paying $316 million to acquire Beceem, a closely held provider of semiconductors used to power products for fourth-generation wireless networks.

headline: Dow Hits a Five-Month High
summary: Better-than-expected earnings from Intel and J.P. Morgan Chase helped lift the broader market even as they stumbled, extending stocks' win streak to four consecutive days.

headline: Gold Hits Fresh Record
summary: Gold futures settled above $1,370 for the first time as concerns about global monetary easing increased the metal's allure.

headline: J.P. Morgan Widens Mortgage Review
summary: J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. widened its review of foreclosures to 41 states and 115,000 loan files, the latest U.S. bank to take a more comprehensive look at its documentation to ensure all information is accurate.

headline: Judge Throws Out Suit Over Countrywide Deal
summary: A judge dismissed a lawsuit filed by investors who challenged an $8.4 billion settlement in 2008 between Bank of America and state attorneys general related to predatory-lending accusations.

headline: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea, Meta Financial Group: Biggest Price Decliners (GAP, CASH)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Judge: Stanford, Ex-Executives Must Pay Own Legal Fees
summary: A judge said Lloyd's of London won't have to cover mounting legal bills for jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford and two associates accused of bilking investors out of billions of dollars.

headline: Irish Leader Reaches Out to Opposition
summary: Prime Minister Brian Cowen has written to the leaders of the main opposition parties seeking a meeting, with the objective of creating a cross-party consensus on the government's proposed four-year budgetary plan.

headline: Photos of the Day: Oct. 13
summary: In Wednesday's pictures, basketball players brawl in China, Serbian soccer fans throw flares on a field, Ahmadinejad visits Lebanon and more.

headline: Restructuring Firms Hit by High-Yield Splurge
summary: The wave of corporate restructurings that was expected in the aftermath of the financial crisis has slowed to a crawl due to a surge in investors' appetite for high-yield debt, which is allowing companies to refinance without a painful restructuring.

headline: John Rosenthal: Germany's Jihadi Export
summary: The country's criminal code should allow the arrest of graduates of Afghan and Pakistani terror camps.

headline: Kenneth R. Weinstein: Sarkozy's Russian Gamble
summary: The French president courts Moscow and maybe trouble.

headline: How to Write a Resignation Letter
summary: A reader asks for tips on what to include in a resignation letter.

headline: Oil Ends Two-Day Decline
summary: Crude -oil futures settled higher, breaking a two-day slide after data showed China's oil imports hit record levels and the dollar weakened.

headline: Why Wall Street May Love a Punishing Election
summary: David Weidner on how a political shift may influence the fate of Dodd-Frank financial overhaul.

headline: European Stocks Rally
summary: A larger-than-expected rebound in euro-zone industrial production helped boost stock-market sentiment, on top of cheer over the prospects of more U.S. stimulus.

headline: French Retailer Casino's Sales Grow Modestly
summary: French retailer Casino reported 0.7% growth in third-quarter sales from continuing operations, as its Latin American business offset weak consumption in France.

headline: UBS Plans 'Transparency Report'
summary: UBS is set to give shareholders more insight into how it nearly collapsed in 2008, but the bank's efforts to quell fury with former managers may fall short of some investors' expectations.

headline: Witnesses in Ghailani Trial Recount Embassy Bombing
summary: Several witnesses at the trial of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the first detainee from Guantanamo Bay to face trial in the U.S., recounted their experiences during the 1998 U.S. embassy bombing in Tanzania.

headline: BAA Loses Airports Ruling
summary: The U.K. Court of Appeal ruled BAA must sell Stansted Airport and either Edinburgh or Glasgow airport, as required by the Competition Commission.

headline: Lloyds to Cut 1,600 Jobs
summary: Lloyds said that it will cut 1,600 permanent jobs in its information-technology and operations department by 2012, as the lender continues to restructure.

headline: Charts Point to Financial-Stock Breakout
summary: While financial stocks have missed much of the broader market's recent rally, chart watchers are cautiously optimistic that the underperforming sector may be poised for a breakout.

headline: Standard Chartered's Puzzling Rights Issue
summary: Standard Chartered's decision to tap shareholders for an extra $5.2 billion is a puzzle.

headline: Ahmadinejad Visits Lebanon
summary: Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad arrived in Beirut Wednesday to cheers from crowds of adoring Lebanese Shiites. The trip, his first state visit to the Arab nation, is seen as a move to bolster Tehran's ally, Hezbollah.

headline: View Darkens on NetSpend IPO
summary: The prepaid debit-card company's preferred issuer, MetaBank, must discontinue originations in its iAdvance line-of-credit program under an OTS directive.

headline: The Short Sale Alternative
summary: While the foreclosure market stalls out, an alternative way to buy distressed property is starting to look more desirable–despite shortcomings.

headline: Société Générale To Appeal Fine
summary: Société Générale said it will appeal a fine imposed in September by the French competition authority for fixing the price of clearing checks electronically.

headline: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea, Meta Financial Group: Biggest Price Decliners (GAP, CASH)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Siga Surges On Expected Contract for Antiviral
summary: Siga Technologies said the government intends to award a contract to the company for a smallpox antiviral, pending resolution of a complaint by a rival bidder.

headline: N.Y. Judge Throws Out Suit Over Countrywide Deal
summary: None

headline: Lebanese Differ on Ahmadinejad's Visit
summary: With Iran's president visiting Lebanon this week, there's a vast gulf between opinions about whether the leader's trip is beneficial or disastrous for Lebanon.

headline: Chile-Mine Rescue in the News
summary: Newspapers around South America and world-wide put the Chile mine rescue on their front pages Wednesday. After more than two months underground, the miners were being brought to the surface one by one. Take a look at the news as reported.

headline: Hong Kong Targets Housing Prices
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang unveiled measures to increase housing supply and reduce hot-money inflows into real estate in an effort to tackle a source of growing public discontent.

headline: Bank of Japan May Buy More Assets
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Masaaki Shirakawa hinted that the central bank may expand its recently announced 5 trillion yen program to purchase a range of financial assets to spur the deflation-strapped economy.

headline: Coal India Plans to Invest in U.S.
summary: State-run Coal India plans to invest in the U.S. for high-quality thermal coal, Chairman Partha Bhattacharyya said.

headline: U.K. Looks to Privatize Royal Mail
summary: The U.K. government took the first step towards privatization of the national postal service as it announced a bill which, if made law, would allow the government to sell shares in Royal Mail for the first time.

headline: Wine 101: Cabernet Sauvignon
summary: When people describe red wine in general, the characteristics often listed are that of Cabernet Sauvignon – the paradigm grape that has set the standard for many of the world's top reds. Why? Because it's consistently popular.

headline: Weber Sets Himself Apart from ECB Council
summary: Strident remarks by Germany's top central banker this week indicate that Axel Weber is moving into the home stretch in the race for the European Central Bank's top job, coming open next October.

headline: Japan Machinery Orders Rise
summary: A leading indicator of business investment in Japan was surprisingly strong in August, a sign many firms may be gearing up to spend, though risks remain.

headline: Fan Flares Interrupt Italy-Serbia Match
summary: A soccer match in Italy Tuesday was abandoned after seven minutes when Serbia fans threw flares and fireworks onto the field.

headline: Joseph Sternberg: Nobel Sentiments, Business Risks
summary: Liu Xiaobo's peace prize raises some telling questions for executives.

headline: Australia's Lonely Central Bank
summary: Australia's economy stood alone among developed countries in passing through the global financial crisis without a recession.

headline: With IPO Done, Mongolia Mining Is on M&A Trail
summary: Mongolia Mining Corp. is looking for acquisition targets in the Mongolian resources sector following an initial public offering in Hong Kong that raised $650 million, according to its top executive. Its shares rose 4.7% on their debut.

headline: Intuit Readies Mobile Products for Businesses
summary: Intuit is prepping as many as five new mobile products for small businesses, the latest evidence the software company's two-year-old research-and-development strategy is delivering results that it expects to drive profits.

headline: Lockheed to Sell Unit for $815 Million
summary: Lockheed agreed to sell a risk and resource management business to Veritas Capital for $815 million.

headline: Indian Tennis Champion Turns Talent Agent
summary: India's Mahesh Bhupathi is known for his 11 tennis Grand Slam titles. Now he's trying to represent more and more emerging talent. In his stable already: top Indian women's tennis player Sania Mirza and Bollywood star Saif Ali Khan.

headline: GMAC Expands Foreclosure Review
summary: GMAC Mortgage is initiating an independent review of foreclosures in all 50 states and examining foreclosure sales nationwide to ensure procedures and documentation are accurate.

headline: Uranium Miner Expects Profit Hit
summary: Energy Resources of Australia downgraded its annual production guidance and said a strong Australian dollar is hurting its bottom line.

headline: Asia Rises on Japan, China Data
summary: Asian stock market indexes ended higher, with Hong Kong's market rising to a 28-month high while Japanese stocks rose after upbeat machinery orders data.

headline: French Strike Enters Second Day
summary: French protests against President Nicolas Sarkozy's plans to increase the retirement age reached a turning point as unions tried to orchestrate crippling strikes—with mixed results.

headline: India May Give More Funds to Capitalize Banks
summary: India's federal government may give 40 billion rupees ($898.8 million)-50 billion rupees above the budgeted amount this fiscal year to capitalize state-run banks, a senior finance ministry official said

headline: Japan's Exceptional Machine Orders
summary: Good economic news from Japan so often proves to be fleeting. Data out Wednesday are no exception.

headline: Euro-Zone Industrial Output Climbs
summary: Industrial production across the 16 countries that share the euro rose more than expected in August, a sign that the sector continued to drive the economic recovery in the third quarter.

headline: U.K. Unemployment Drops
summary: U.K. unemployment dropped to the lowest rate in more than a year, but the more timely claimant count measure rose for a second straight month, highlighting the risks ahead.

headline: ndia Beat Australia in Second Test
summary: India beat Australia by seven wickets in the second cricket test in Bangalore to win the series 2-0. Some snapshots.

headline: Cidron Raises Bid for Munters
summary: Cidron Intressenter raised its bid for Swedish indoor humidity-control systems maker Munters to $868.7 million, trumping a bid from a rival.

headline: Vinashin Names New Chairman
summary: Vietnam appointed a PetroVietnam senior executive to take over Vinashin, which has fallen under scrutiny after the arrests of top managers.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: India's men's field hockey team in New Delhi, festival celebrations in Amritsar, Saina Nehwal in the badminton semi-final match at the Commonwealth Games and more.

headline: Legg Mason Targets Asia's 'Fertile Fields'
summary: Chairman and CEO Mark Fetting says with the rapid growth of wealthy individuals in Asia, the asset manager's international business is "leading the charge" of the company's recovery.

headline: NEC Invests in Cloud Computing
summary: NEC of Japan will invest $1.2 billion in the coming years, mainly in cloud computing and overseas information technology, as it joins global technology players pinning their hopes on the field.

headline: Geithner: Yuan Should Rise Significantly
summary: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said the U.S. wants to make sure the yuan appreciates "at a gradual but still significant rate."

headline: Wal-Mart Plans Small Stores
summary: Wal-Mart is planning to open dozens of small stores in the nation's cities in an effort to push back against the dollar chains and other competitors nibbling at its customers.

headline: Don't-Ask Policy Is Halted By Judge
summary: A federal judge in California issued a broad injunction barring the military from enforcing its "don't ask, don't tell" policy, which is aimed at prohibiting openly gay people from serving in the military.

headline: Darrelle Revis Has Sore Hamstring
summary: The Jets' Darrelle Revis seems uncertain he'll play this week after saying his hamstring was sore, and Two elite runners drop out of the New York Marathon. Plus, the Mets continue interviewing potential GMs and more.

headline: Google to Fund Power Project
summary: Google and two other companies pledged to invest tens of millions of dollars in a new offshore wind-energy project that, if completed, could allow 1.9 million households to obtain energy from turbines off the East Coast.

headline: Jon Kyl: A Growth Agenda for America
summary: An economy grows through increased production, which is financed by capital or savings. Congress can encourage this process with the right tax reform.

headline: Investors Unite to Challenge Ameritrade on Defunct Fund
summary: Investors trapped for two years in the defunct Reserve Yield Plus Fund they bought through TD Ameritrade are threatening the broker with a new wave of negative publicity unless it makes them whole.

headline: Clinton Urges End to Animosity in Balkans
summary: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton visited Balkan capitals Tuesday, urging leaders to set aside ethnic animosities and catch up with their neighbors on the path to integration with the EU.

headline: Isilon Systems Lures Traders Looking to Ride Deal Wave
summary: Sometimes, options traders don't even need to be correct about a deal to make money.

headline: The Sounds of Alarm Clocks
summary: From notoriously deep-sleeping college students to sleep-deprived parents, many people have a hard time getting out of bed in the morning. Manufacturers are responding with a range of clocks, from ear-splitting "sonic bombs" to others that feature pleasant aromas and nature sounds. Listen to a sampling.

headline: China's Democratic Conversation
summary: Far from a Western conceit, talk of freedom surfaces at every opportunity.

headline: Bellwether District Hangs in Balance
summary: If Republicans are to take back the House on Nov. 2, the wave that sweeps them to power will come in areas like the Third House District in rural Washington.

headline: CSX Profit Jumps on Volume Gains
summary: Railroad operator CSX reported third-quarter profit climbed 43%, a record for the period, as revenue jumped due to overall volume gains, which helped results top Wall Street's expectations.

headline: Germany's Weber Criticizes Bond Buys
summary: Germany's top central banker urged the ECB to halt purchases of the government debt of countries such as Greece and Ireland.

headline: In Havana, Intimate Encounters
summary: Wynton Marsalis's role during Jazz at Lincoln Center's five-day residency in Havana was supposed to be as teacher, but it also bolstered his own education in the importance of ancestry to Cuban jazz tradition.

headline: More Ethanol to Be Allowed in Cars
summary: The Obama administration plans to allow higher levels of ethanol for gasoline used by newer cars, a step that would benefit corn growers but has been opposed by livestock ranchers, auto makers and oil refiners.

headline: U.S. Ends Ban on Deep-Water Drilling
summary: The Obama administration said it is lifting a controversial moratorium on deep-water oil drilling, but it's unclear how quickly idled oil rigs can go back to work in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Paladino Says He's Sorry Now
summary: Saying he's a "simple man" who makes mistakes, Republican gubernatorial candidate Carl Paladino apologized Tuesday for comments he made about gays that provoked charges of homophobia.

headline: Jets Turn Over a New Leaf
summary: Mark Sanchez played interception- and fumble-free football against the Vikings, and the Jets extended an impressive streak: They became the 13th team in NFL history to play four straight games without a turnover.

headline: Del Posto Latest on Lawsuit Menu
summary: Twenty-seven current and former workers at celebrity chef Mario Batali's highly acclaimed Del Posto filed a lawsuit in federal court in Manhattan seeking tips and wages they are allegedly owed.

headline: Honeywell Leads in Political Giving
summary: Amid this year's heated debate over corporate campaign cash, the top donor to House and Senate campaigns is a company that was an also-ran in political Washington just a few years ago: Honeywell International.

headline: Dow Makes 'Golden Cross'
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average crossed the 11000 mark on Friday for the first time since May 3. Investors tend to get giddy when a benchmark index hits a large round number.

headline: U.K. Consumer Confidence Weakens
summary: British consumers became more pessimistic about the outlook for the economy and the jobs market during September, and less willing to make major purchases, according to a monthly survey.

headline: Scoundrels and Pensions
summary: How to avoid another Alan Hevesi.

headline: What to Wear While on a Diet
summary: Fashion reporter Teri Agins answers a reader's question about good clothing styles during a diet.

headline: Home Deals in Suburbs Start to Dry Up
summary: Manhattan's bedroom communities have undergone a boomlet in sales and rising prices as city dwellers have been looking for housing bargains in nearby suburbs that were hard hit during the downturn.

headline: Cities Understate Pension Liabilities
summary: Many of the largest U.S. municipalities are understating the true size of their pension obligations by using inappropriate accounting methods, according to a study released Tuesday.

headline: Con Coughlin: The Afghanistan War's Dividends in Europe
summary: The West's engagements there and in Pakistan have yielded the information edge we need to pre-empt terror threats.

headline: Your Responsibility for Health Care
summary: Michael Milken's point in "Toward a New American Century" (op-ed, Oct. 7) on the importance of personal responsibility in controlling health-care costs is not just theory, but is supported by results obtained in both corporate and state programs.

headline: Hitting Takes a Break in Baseball Playoffs
summary: If you love pitching duels, strikeouts and fast-paced games, this year's baseball postseason has been a dream.

headline: France Stands Against Turkey EU Bid
summary: French Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner told Turkey that "the ball is in your court" if it wants to rescue its troubled bid to join the EU, but made it clear that France hasn't changed its opposition to Turkey's membership.

headline: AOL, Firms Explore Yahoo Offer
summary: AOL and several private-equity firms are exploring a possible bid for Yahoo, devising a bold plan to marry two big Internet brands facing steep challenges. The discussions are preliminary and don't include Yahoo.

headline: Mamet With an Accent
summary: Sir Patrick Stewart's performance in David Mamet's "A Life in the Theatre," at the Schoenfeld Theatre, is deeply comprehending and painfully touching, just like the play itself.

headline: Suspect Was Penny Foolish
summary: A Long Island gas-station worker was charged with stealing $30,000 over 2 ½ months by manipulating prices on the station's computer and pocketing the difference.

headline: Monaco Bachelor Pad
summary: This refurbished waterfront duplex apartment in Monaco's CarrÃ© d'Or is the ultimate jet-setting bachelor pad.

headline: U.S. Sues Over Ballots
summary: The Justice Department sued New York state, seeking to force the state to count late ballots cast by military members and other absentee voters overseas because the state was tardy in sending out the ballots.

headline: Keeping Tabs on Joint Replacements
summary: A new nationwide registry will collect data on hip and knee replacements in order to uncover implant problems more quickly.

headline: Housing Data Show Pluses
summary: Despite the country's lingering housing weakness, New York City's residential sales saw another quarter of strength. The average sales price of a home in New York City was up 7% from a year earlier.

headline: When Canada Almost Ruled the Civil Skies
summary: One very significant development, omitted in Dan Michaels's review of Sam Howe Verhovek's "Jet Age" ("Shrinking the World—How jetliners commercialized air travel—stewardesses and all," Books, Oct. 9) with regard to the progress of the jet age, occurred in Canada where Avro Canada designed and flew the four-engined "Jetliner C102,"

headline: The Confusing Shades of Green Cars
summary: In Eyes on the Road, Joe White looks at the challenge auto makers face explaining all the green alternatives to consumers.

headline: Blood Aside, Herschel Walker Prefers MMA
summary: Former NFL pro-bowler Herschel Walker says mixed martial arts is safer than football, some bets at California race tracks get costlier, and some Bernie Williams postseason records are precarious.

headline: Probe Targets Foreclosure Paperwork
summary: A Florida probe is focusing on paperwork by a Georgia mortgage-processing company that may have tainted tens of thousands of foreclosures.

headline: Jenkins: NFL vs. 'TV Everywhere'
summary: TV's fight against Napsterization is far from won.

headline: PG&E Outlines Plans for Safer Pipelines
summary: PG&E outlined plans to upgrade its California pipeline system to boost safety, a month after eight people were killed when one of its natural-gas pipelines exploded.

headline: Macs Get New Outlook
summary: Microsoft improved each of the key components for its new Mac version of Office, which finally includes a robust version of Outlook, writes Walt Mossberg.

headline: China: Liu's Jailing Is Internal Issue
summary: China warned foreign politicians not to interfere in its internal affairs, as the U.S. urged Beijing to lift restrictions on the movements of the wife of Liu Xiaobo, the jailed Chinese dissident awarded the Nobel Peace Prize last week.

headline: Major Grower to Join Wage Plan
summary: Pacific Tomato Growers said it would distribute to workers a penny-per-pound surcharge that major tomato buyers such as McDonald's have offered to pay for their product.

headline: Calpers Plan for Rating Firms: Let Investors Vote
summary: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest public pension fund and a major bond buyer, is offering a new twist on bond raters' business models: Put ratings to an investor vote, and divvy up revenues accordingly.

headline: A Long Shot, but Bielat Could Win
summary: Regarding James Taranto's "The Marine Who Has Barney Frank Worried" (Cross Country, Oct. 9): If Sean Bielat concentrates on the southern tier, it is not at all impossible for him to send Mr. Frank home in January.

headline: Invista Done as Firm Exits
summary: Invista Real Estate Investment Management Holdings, the U.K.'s largest listed real-estate fund manager, said it will wind down its business after it lost one of its biggest clients, Lloyds Banking Group.

headline: Joan Sutherland: The Queen of Bel Canto
summary: Joan Sutherland changed the operatic landscape with a voice of remarkable range, power, and creamy, effortless beauty that shone brightest in operas emphasizing pure line and vocal agility.

headline: Law Firm to Pay $550,000 in Pension Probe
summary: A national law firm embroiled in an ongoing investigation of New York State's public pension fund, Manatt Phelps & Phillips, has agreed to a $550,000 settlement with Cuomo.

headline: Loft Showcases a Furniture Dealer's Picks
summary: Evan Lobel handpicked vintage furnishings for his roughly 2,500-square-foot loft during visits to high-end homes from Manhattan to Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Iraq Oil Is 'Game Changer'
summary: The revival in Iraqi oil production will be a "game-changer" for global oil supplies and a challenge for other big oil producers like Saudi Arabia.

headline: More Light on Nontraditional Types of Illumination
summary: Your editorial "Let There Be Lightbulbs" (Oct. 7) provides a distorted picture of the upcoming phase-out of inefficient lightbulbs. The phase-out is good for consumers and the environment, and will create jobs in the U.S.

headline: Debit-Card Issuer Sues the Fed
summary: Debit-card issuer TCF sued the Federal Reserve, seeking to halt forthcoming rules on debit-card transactions that could hurt the bank's revenue.

headline: Greece's Borrowing Costs Fall
summary: Greece's deficit-reduction efforts are bearing some fruit in the debt markets, where the nation sold a batch of short-term bills at a yield lower than a previous, similar auction.

headline: Piper Jaffray to Spin Off Private-Capital Business
summary: Piper Jaffray Cos. unveiled plans to spin off its private-capital business by year's end to the segment's key principals as it is renamed North Sky Capital.

headline: Starbucks Reins In Baristas
summary: Starbucks is changing the way its baristas make some of its espresso drinks, which some employees worry will result in longer lines.

headline: Why Cnooc in Texas Should Worry the Kremlin
summary: Buying into a joint venture with Chesapeake Energy, Cnooc Ltd. must have been looking over its shoulder for rabid U.S. regulators. But it is Moscow that should really be concerned.

headline: New Day for Home Builders
summary: Some home builders that collapsed during the early years of the housing bust are emerging from bankruptcy with less debt, choice land holdings and sharpened business plans, giving them a competitive advantage.

headline: Joba Fades Into a Secondary Role
summary: With the emergence of Phil Hughes as a starter and the acquisition of Kerry Wood, Joba Chamberlain has been forced to accept a diminished role out of the Yankees bullpen.

headline: Tech Revival Boosts San Francisco
summary: San Francisco's is enjoying a renaissance as a technology center, as numerous Web and digital-media companies move in or expand in a burst of economic activity not seen since the dot-com boom of the '90s.

headline: U.K. University Students Face Higher Fees
summary: University students in England face the prospect of a steep increase in tuition fees after a government-ordered report recommended that the current cap on should be removed.
